statement:
Let $f\colon[a,b]\to \mathbf R$ be a continuous function, let
$c\in[a,b]$ be given and consider the integral function $F$ defined on
$[a,b]$ as $$F(x)= \int_c^x f(t)\, dt.$$

Then $F$ is an antiderivative of $f$ that is, $F$ is differentiable in
$[a,b]$ and $$F'(x)=f(x)\qquad \forall x\in [a,b].$$

The previous relation rewritten as
$$\frac{d}{dx} \int_c^x f(t)\, dt = f(x)$$ shows that the
differentiation operator $\frac{d}{dx}$ is the inverse of the
integration operator $\int_c^x$. This formula is sometimes called
Newton-Leibniz formula.

On the other hand if $f\colon[a,b]\to \mathbf R$ is a continuous
function and $G\colon[a,b]\to \mathbf R$ is any antiderivative of $f$,
i.e. $G'(x)=f(x)$ for all $x\in[a,b]$, then $$\label{eq:barrow}
  \int_a^b f(t) \, dt = G(b)-G(a).$$

This shows that up to a constant, the integration operator is the
inverse of the derivative operator: $$\int_a^x D G = G - G(a).$$

Notes {#notes .unnumbered}
=====

Equation  is sometimes called “Barrow’s rule” or “Barrow’s formula”.
